Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Planning Grant: EV-TEC Site for Realization of Energy Efficient Ground Vehicles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The planned University of Louisville (UL) site of the Electric Vehicle Transportation and Electricity Convergence (EV-TEC) I/UCRC will have a research focus on realizing energy efficient ground vehicles (REEGV). Topic areas include hybrid and hybrid electric powertrain systems, lightweight structures, high performance computing tools for vehicle architecture optimization, conventional powertrains, frictional loss management, and advanced automotive manufacturing methods.

The University of Louisville J.B. Speed School of Engineering has committed to developing and launching an interdisciplinary graduate certificate program in automotive engineering by the end of the planning period, followed by an interdisciplinary Master of Science program in automotive engineering one year later. The university and Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) plans to establish a professional chapter in this region in support of the industry. Finally the UL site will sponsor an REEGV research seminar series, student projects, and an SAE Supermileage team.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of award number 1439669 was to facilitate planning activities involved with the University of Louisville (UofL) joining EV-TEC (Electric Vehicles: Transportation Energy Convergence), an existing Industry/University Cooperative Research Center with sites at Texas A&M University (lead institution) and the University of Texas at Austin. UofL’s mission area was to be efficient and sustainable ground vehicles with an emphasis on vehicle systems, which complimented EV-TEC’s original focus on transportation systems and electric power infrastructure. 

At the time award 1439669 was made, EV-TEC was nearing the end of its Phase I funding cycle. Subsequent to the award, EV-TEC stakeholders, including NSF, decided that the center would not submit a phase 2 renewal proposal. Based upon continued interest in efficient/sustainable vehicles by faculty at UofL and its prospective site members, NSF gave the university the option of using the site planning grant to establish a standalone center in this area, with the stipulation that no funding beyond the original planning grant would be provided. This offer was accepted. The new center-in-planning was named Efficient Vehicles and Sustainable Transportation Systems (EV-STS). UofL was joined in the planning effort by five partner institutions: University of Alabama, Arizona State University, State University of New York at Buffalo, University of Tennessee, and University of Texas at Austin. Four primary research thrust areas were incorporated into the center mission: electrified vehicle powertrains, advanced conventional powertrains, efficient non-powertrain systems, and ground transportation systems and infrastructure.

The intellectual merit for the EV-STS initiative lies in its effort to synergize the needs of a diverse group of automotive/ground transportation stakeholders with academic research capabilities that cover a coherent mission domain without sacrificing industrial relevance. Ultimately, this synergy and relevance needed to be demonstrated to NSF and potential industrial members at a planning meeting that provided both a comprehensive overview of the proposed center's value proposition, and tangible illustration of research relevance in the form of proposals that might be integrated into the center's year 1 project portfolio. The initiative's broader impact contributions lie in its objective of establishing a center capable of contributing to the solution of one the most important problems of our time: assuring the long-term sustainability of ground vehicles and transportation systems, while simultaneously maintaining their economic viability. 

Collectively, an EV-STS leadership team consisting of the provisional site directors, interested faculty researchers, and representatives from key potential members formulated a vision statement, formal mission statement, and research thrust area summary for the proposed center. Potential industrial members were recruited based upon congruence with the target industry and research mission. A center-in-planning website and information/recruitment package consisting of a value proposition presentation, draft membership agreement, and draft center bylaws were collaboratively developed. 

The planning meeting was held June 15-16, 2015, at the Seelbach Hotel in Louisville, Kentucky. All six provisional site directors participated, as did 28 additional faculty members. Representatives from 33 potential center members attended.
